metadata.case_name: State v. Manshankar Prabhasbankar Dwivedi & Vallabhdas Gordhandas Thakkar
metadata.case_number: Cr. A. Nos. 190 and 191 of 1969, and 63 and 64 of 1972

facts.text: Manshankar Prabhasbankar Dwivedi was a Senior Lecturer at the D.K.V. Arts Science College, Jamnagar, a Government college.
Vallabhdas Gordhandas Thakkar was a legal practitioner conducting cases before Income tax and Sales tax Departments, resident of Jamnagar.
In April 1964, Physics practical examination for first year B.Sc. held by Gujarat University, one centre at Surendranagar; Dwivedi appointed as Examiner for Physics practical.

Dwivedi accepted gratification of Rs. 500/- other than legal remuneration through Thakkar for showing favour to candidate Jayendra Jayantilal Shah by giving more marks than deserved in Physics practical.
Dwivedi charged under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(d) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.
Thakkar charged under s.165A IPC and s.5(2) of the Act r/w s.114 IPC.
Special Judge tried both, found guilty, sentenced each to 2 years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs.1,000/-, in default further RI for six months.
Both convicted filed appeals to Gujarat High Court; High Court found prosecution case proved on merits but acquitted on interpretation of sections.

Pranlal Mohanlal, complainant and brother-in-law of student Jayendra, went to college with panch witness Shivaji; Thakkar in porch demanded money for Dwivedi; Pranlal insisted on talking to Dwivedi first.
Thakkar followed to Trolley Station, took them to Vikram Lodge, again demanded money; Pranlal repeated insistence.

At about 11 A.M., returned to college first floor outside exam hall; Thakkar brought Dwivedi; Dwivedi said 'why are you delaying. You are a fool you will spoil the life of the student. Pay the amount to Thakkar.'
Pranlal paid Rs.500/- to Thakkar in presence of Dwivedi; Thakkar counted and pocketed; Dwivedi went back; signal given, raiding party arrived, recoveries made, panchnamas prepared.
High Court agreed with Special Judge that prosecution case of demand and acceptance of Rs.500/- bribe for more marks to Jayendra proved.
State filed appeals by certificate (Cr. As. 190,191/1969, defective) and special leave (Cr. As. 63,64/1972, granted).

legal_issues.text: Whether Dwivedi was a public servant within s.21 Ninth clause IPC in capacity as Examiner of Gujarat University, independent of his government lecturer position.

Whether Dwivedi committed offence under s.5(1)(d) Prevention of Corruption Act by corrupt means abusing position as public servant, even if act done in capacity as University Examiner not as government servant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dwivedi covered under last part of Ninth clause s.21 IPC as officer in service/pay of Government or remunerated by fee/commission for performance of public duty as Examiner.

Under s.5(1)(d) PC Act, liability absolute for public servant obtaining valuable thing by corrupt/illegal means; immaterial if not in discharge of duty or abusing position as PS; proved he is govt servant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(1)(d) PC Act; Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration

respondent_arguments.text: Examiner of University not public servant under s.21 Ninth clause as does not hold 'office'; context requires connection with Government; private persons also appointed examiners.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.21 IPC Ninth clause; Gujarat University Act ss.20,30; Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Delhi Administration

respondent_arguments.text: s.5(1)(d) PC Act requires abuse of position as public servant; bribe taken in capacity as examiner, not as govt lecturer; 'by corrupt/illegal means or by otherwise abusing position as PS' read together.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(1)(d) PC Act; M. Narayanan Nambiar v. State of Kerala; Ram Krishna v. State of Delhi

court_reasoning.text: University Examiner does not hold 'office' under Ninth clause s.21 IPC; no requirement in Gujarat University Act for govt servants/office holders; private qualified persons appointed; amendment 1964 clarifies intent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Examiner cannot be considered holder of office; Ram Krishna Dalmia supports.

court_reasoning.text: s.5(1)(d) PC Act requires abuse of position as public servant essential ingredient, whether by corrupt/illegal means or otherwise; Dwivedi acted as examiner, not abusing lecturer position; analysis of clause consistent with other clauses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court reasoning sound; precedents like Narayanan Nambiar indicate abuse of PS position necessary.

court_reasoning.text: Thakkar not guilty if Dwivedi not guilty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Offences under s.165A IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.114 IPC depend on Dwivedi's guilt.

holdings.text: University Examiner not public servant under s.21 Ninth clause IPC unless holding office connected to govt service.
Offence u/s 5(1)(d) PC Act requires public servant to abuse position as such; not committed if act in non-PS capacity despite being PS otherwise.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Delhi Administration
precedents_cited.relevance: Chartered Accountant investigator not holding office, hence not PS under Ninth clause despite govt remuneration for public duty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration
precedents_cited.relevance: Not necessary for misconduct in discharge of own duty under s.5(1)(d); overruled State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier view requiring misconduct in discharge of duty rejected.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. Narayanan Nambiar v. State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Abuse of position as PS essential; 'otherwise' qualifies means savouring dishonest act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Krishna v. The State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Analysis of s.5(1)(d) offences; abuse of PS position implied across clauses.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges under ss.161,165A,114; definition of public servant under s.21 key to s.161.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Criminal misconduct by PS; s.2 adopts IPC s.21 definition; abuse of position essential.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat University Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointment of examiners by Syndicate; no restriction to govt servants/office holders.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Gujarat High Court's acquittal of Dwivedi and Thakkar; Dwivedi not public servant as University Examiner under s.21 IPC Ninth clause, no abuse of PS position under s.5(1)(d) PC Act as act in examiner capacity; Thakkar not guilty consequentially.

key_quotes.text: 'why are you delaying. You are a fool you will spoil the life of the student. Pay the amount to Thakkar.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dwivedi's words urging payment, part of proved trap.

key_quotes.text: A University Examiner cannot be considered to hold an office in the sense in which that word has been understood and employed in the Ninth Clause.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on public servant definition.

key_quotes.text: The gist of the offence under this clause is that a public officer abusing his position as a public servant obtains for himself or for any other person any valuable thing or pecuniary advantage.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation of s.5(1)(d) requiring abuse of PS position.
